content:
.Fundamen-
tal rights concern such things as the right to vote or the right to procreate. A
classification is suspect if it concerns race, religion, national origin, and so on.
Under the new interpretation of the equal protection clause, states could still
pass laws restricting fundamental rights, and these laws could still employ sus-
pect  classifications,  but,  when  they  did  so,  a  heavy  burden  of  proof  fell  on
them. To justify such a law, the state had to show that (1) the legislat
